project.project_name: NASA- Air Quality Daily and Annual NO2 Concentrations

resource.resource_name: Di et al. (2020) Daily and Annual NO2 Concentrations for the Contiguous United States, 1-km Grids, v1.10 (2000 – 2016)
resource.resource_description: The Daily and Annual NO2 Concentrations for the Contiguous United States, 1-km Grids, Version 1.10 (2000-2016) dataset contains nitrogen dioxide (NO2) air pollution concentration estimates. NO2 concentrations are estimated using an ensemble modeling approach with three machine learning models (neural network, random forest, and gradient boosting) and a generalized additive model. The approach incorporates satellite-based observations of NO2 column concentrations, land use and meteorological variables, chemical transport models, and other data sources. This dataset provides daily and annual average NO2 concentration estimates during 2000 to 2016 for the contiguous United States with 1 km spatial resolution.

resource_reference.resource_reference_text: Di, Q., Wei, Y., Shtein, A., Xing, X., Amini, H., Hultquist, C., Shi, L., Kloog, I., Silvern, R., Kelly, J., Sabath, M. B., Choirat, C., Koutrakis, P., Lyapustin, A., Wang, Y., Mickley, L. J., Daouk, Y., & Schwartz, J. (2024). Daily and Annual NO2 Concentrations for the Contiguous United States, 1-km Grids, Version 1.10 (2000 - 2016) (Version 1.10) [Data set]. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC).

publication.citation: Di, Q., Amini, H., Shi, L., Kloog, I., Silvern, R., Kelly, J., ... & Schwartz, J. (2019). Assessing NO2 concentration and model uncertainty with high spatiotemporal resolution across the contiguous United States using ensemble model averaging. Environmental science & technology, 54(3), 1372-1384.

example_metrics: Daily average NO2 air pollution concentration for grid cell containing geocoded address

intended_use.value: Geospatial exposure assessment for studies on shorter-term health outcomes (e.g., acute conditions) or longer-term health outcomes (e.g., chronic conditions)
Geospatial exposure assessment at the individual-level or population-level

strengths: Dataset supports analysis of shorter-term and longer-term exposure to NO2 air pollution across the contiguous US using consistent methods
Dataset incorporates imputation of missing values to provide high coverage (completeness) of predictions within the spatial and temporal extent
limitations: Dataset does not include model estimates of uncertainty (e.g., confidence intervals for predictions)
Dataset cannot be used to compare exposures within the same grid cell or at different times of day
